I'd like to point out that CPPNs can be combined effectively with 
cellular=
 growth models. Because the cells need the answer to the 
question "Who am =
I?", the CPPN can provide that info without any 
interaction between cells.=
 It can also provide instructions about, for 
example "Should I divide or n=
ot? Should I change my type?". 
While it seems like an overkill, because CP=
PNs already abstract this 
away without having to introduce time for develo=
pment, the patterns 
generated are hard to interpret as distinct physical o=
bjects. 
Especially in cases of repeating patterns. But objects generated w=
ith 
cellular growth instructed by CPPNs produce only a single object, all =

with its distinct parts and regularities. And not ripped apart with 
artif=
acts as it would be after converting it from a CPPN snapshot 
image. One mi=
ght say that such objects can still be infinte in size, 
but it is easy to =
put a limitation on the number of cells or cell 
divisions. It is also poss=
ible to make the limit dynamic, more complex 
CPPNs producing phenotypes wi=
th more cells.

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <ksta=
nley@...> wrote:
>
> Alexandre, thank you for bringing up reaction-diffusio=
n systems.  
You
> make a good point- my statement was too broad, in part b=
ecause
> "cellular growth model" is a fairly ambiguous term that can
> pote=
ntially refer to many types of systems.  
> 
> Just to clarify my statement=
, I was responding the line of 
discussion
> with Peter about encodings tha=
t actually create distinct bodily 
shapes
> that are self-contained and hav=
e clear structural boundaries (which
> reaction-diffusion systems tend not =
to produce; rather they produce
> wallpaper-like patterns).  Often when gro=
wth-based models are used 
to
> define actual bodies with distinct borders,=
 they are studied in the
> context of blobs with a particular focus on how =
the blob knows when 
to
> stop growing so that a border shape can be create=
d.  That kind of
> systems goes along with the "skin" issue that we were di=
scussing.
> 
> Nevertheless, the field is quite broad and there are many po=
ssible
> interesting examples of such systems.  If I could revisit my
> sta=
tement, I would reword it such as to avoid implying any sweeping
> generali=
zation.
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <mar=
makoide@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello
> > 
> > "Along these lines, I have rarely s=
een a cellular growth model
> produce anything more than a blob or an amorp=
hous shape without 
clear
> parts."
> > 
> > If you consider reaction-diffu=
sion systems as a cellular growth
> model, then you might consider the foll=
owing publications :
> > "Interactive Evolution of Dynamical Systems, Karl =
Sims"
> > "Advanced Reaction-Diffusion Models for Texture Synthesis, Allen =

R.
> Sanderson et al."
> > 
> > Those patterns are a bit above the average=
 blob and features very
> compact description.

dre Devert
